text.front:
CLASSIFICATION OF SIMPLE WEIGHT MODULES
OVER THE 1-SPATIAL AGEING ALGEBRA
RENCAI L ¨
U, VOLODYMYR MAZORCHUK AND KAIMING ZHAO
Abstract. In this paper we use Block's classification of simple
modules over the first Weyl algebra to obtain a complete classifi-
cation of simple weight modules, in particular, of Harish-Chandra
modules, over the 1-spatial ageing algebra age(1). Most of these
modules have infinite dimensional weight spaces and so far the al-
gebra age(1) is the only Lie algebra having simple weight modules
with infinite dimensional weight spaces for which such a classifica-
tion exists. As an application we classify all simple weight modules
over the (1 + 1)-dimensional space-time Schrödinger algebra S that
have a simple age(1)-submodule thus constructing many new sim-
ple weight S-modules.
Keywords: weight module, Schrödinger algebra, ageing
algebra, highest weight module
Mathematics Subject Classification 2010: 17B10,
17B30, 17B80
text.body:
1. Introduction and description of the results
Non-semisimple Lie algebras play an important role in physics where
they are frequently used to study various physical systems and ex-
plain diverse physical phenomena. For example one could mention
Schrödinger algebras and groups, see [DDM], conformal Galilei algebras
and groups, see [AI, AIK, CZ, GIl, GI2, HP, NOR, LMZ], and ageing
algebras, see [HP, H1, H2, H3, H4, HEP, HU, HS1, HS2, PH, HSSU].
The representation theory of finite dimensional semisimple Lie alge-
bras is fairly well developed, see for example [Hu, Ja, M] and the ref-
erences therein. In contrast to this, many important methods of the
representation theory of semisimple algebra are either not available or
not yet developed or, at best, become much more complicated in the
non-semisimple case, confer e.g. [DLMZ]. As a consequence, much
less in known for non-semisimple case even for Lie algebras of rather
small dimension. Some recent results, see e.g. [WZ, D, DLMZ, LMZ],
make some progress in studying modules over certain non-semisimple
extensions of the Lie algebra sl 2 motivated by their applications in
physics.
text.note:
RENCAI L ¨
U, VOLODYMYR MAZORCHUK AND KAIMING ZHAO
text.body:
The Schrödinger Lie group is the group of symmetries of the free par-
ticle Schrödinger equation. The classical Schr¨ödinger algebra is the Lie
algebra of this group. The main objects of study in this paper is the
extended Schrödinger algebra S in (1 + 1)-dimensional space-time and
its ageing subalgebra age(1), see precise definitions in Section 2. The
name of the latter algebra comes from its use as dynamical symme-
try in physical ageing, which can be observed in strongly interacting
many-body systems quenched from a disordered initial state to the co-
existence regime below the critical temperature T c > 0 where several
equivalent equilibrium states exist, see [BR] for details. Various repre-
sentations of age(1) were constructed in the literature, see for example
[HS1, HS2, H1, H2, H3, H4, HU, PH, HSSU].
Both S and age(1) have natural Cartan subalgebras which allow to
define the notion of weight modules, that is modules on which elements
of the Cartan subalgebra act diagonalizably. The main objective of the
present paper is to classify all simple weight modules over age(1). It
turns out that these modules have either all their weight spaces one-
dimensional, or all their weight spaces infinite dimensional. It seems
that the algebra age(1) is the first Lie algebra having simple weight
modules with infinite dimensional weight spaces for which classification
of simple weight modules is completed. As an application we classify all
simple weight S-modules that have a simple age(1)-submodule. This
provides many new examples of simple weight S-modules (for other
examples, see [D, LMZ]).
The paper is organized as follows. We start with some preliminaries in
Section 2. In Section 3, by embedding our algebras into the first Weyl
algebra we obtain a very good presentation for the centralizer U 0 of the
Cartan subalgebra in the universal enveloping algebra U(age(1)). This
is the key observation needed to classify all simple U 0 -modules. As a
consequence, we obtain our main result, Theorem 11, which provides
a classification of all simple weight modules over age(1). It turns out
that there are four classes of such simple modules, the first three classes
consist of certain weight modules with finite dimensional (in fact one-
dimensional) weight spaces, while the last class consists of modules for
which all non-zero weight spaces are infinite-dimensional. As a bonus,
in Section 4 we classify all simple weight S-modules that have a simple
age(1)-submodule, see Theorem 15.
2. Preliminaries
In this paper, we denote by Z, N, Z + and C the sets of integers, positive
integers, nonnegative integers and complex numbers, respectively. All
vector spaces and Lie algebras are over C. For a Lie algebra g we denote
by U(g) its universal enveloping algebra. We write ⊗ for ⊗ C .
text.note: SIMPLE WEIGHT MODULES OVER AGEING ALGEBRA
text.body:
The extended Schrödinger algebra S in (1+1)-dimensional space-time is
a complex Lie algebra with a basis {f, q, h, e, p, z} and the Lie bracket
given as follows:
(2.1)
[h, e] = 2e, [e, f ] = h, [h, f ] = −2f,
[e, q] = p, [e, p] = 0, [h, p] = p,
[f, p] = q, [f, q] = 0, [h, q] = −q,
[p, q] = z. [z, S] = 0.
It is easy to see that the subspace age(1) of S spanned by {e, h, p, q, z}
is a Lie subalgebra of S. This subalgebra is called the ageing algebra.
The elements h and z span a Cartan subalgebra h while the elements
p, q and z span a copy of the Heisenberg algebra H. We also denote
by n the subalgebra spanned by h, z, e and p. The subalgebra of S
spanned by e, f and h is isomorphic to the classical algebra sl 2 and
will be identified with the latter.
By Schur's lemma, the element z acts as a scalar on any simple module
over age(1) or S. Since we are concerned with simple modules only, we
will assume that z acts as a scalar ˙
z on any module in this paper. For
a module V we denote by wt(V ) the set of h-eigenvalues on V and will
call these eigenvalues weights. All h-eigenvectors will be called weight
vectors. For a weight ˙
h we denote by V ˙
h the corresponding weight space,
that is the space of all h-eigenvectors with eigenvalue ˙
h. If V is a simple
weight age(1)- or S-module, then, as usual, we have wt(V ) ⊂ ˙
h + Z for
any ˙
h ∈ wt(V ).
Let U 0 = {x ∈ U(age(1))|[h, x] = 0} be the centralizer of h in U(age(1)).
Then, as usual, for every simple weight age(1)-module V and any
λ ∈ wt(V ) the U 0 -module V λ is simple.
Each ( ˙
z, ˙
h) ∈ C
2 defines the one-dimensional n-module Cw with the
action hw = ˙
hw, zw = ˙
zw and pw = ew = 0. Using it we define, as
usual, the Verma age(1)-module
M age(1) ( ˙
z, ˙
h) = Ind
age(1)
n
Cw.
Denote by ¯
M age(1) ( ˙
z, ˙
h) the unique simple quotient of M age(1) ( ˙
z, ˙
h) (which
exists by standard arguments, see e.g. [Di, Chapter 7]). Similarly we
may define the Verma modules M S ( ˙
z, ˙
h), M H ( ˙
z), M sl 2 ( ˙
h) and the corre-
sponding simple quotients ¯
M S ( ˙
z, ˙
h), ¯
M H ( ˙
z), ¯
M sl 2 ( ˙
h) over S, H, and sl 2 ,
respectively. Analogously one defines the lowest weight Verma modules
M
−
S ( ˙

−

( ˙

text.note:
RENCAI L ¨
U, VOLODYMYR MAZORCHUK AND KAIMING ZHAO
text.body:
3. Simple weight modules over age(1)
We start by recalling some results from [B] adjusted to our setup. Let
K be the associative algebra C(t)[s] where st − ts = 1. The algebra K
is a non-commutative principal left and right ideal domain, in fact, it is
an Euclidean domain (both left and right). The space C(t) becomes a
faithful C(t)[s]-module by defining the action of C(t) via multiplication
and the action of s via
d
dt
. Consider the subalgebra R 0 of K generated
by t and t
2 s, and the subalgebra R 1 of K generated by t and ts. For
convenience of later use we set R ˙
z := R 1 for ˙
z ∈ C
* .
Lemma 1. Let ˙
z ∈ C.
(a) Let α =
n
j=0 α j s
j , where α j ∈ C(t) with α 0 = 1, be an irreducible
element in K. Then we have the following:
(i) If the rational function α j has a zero at 0 of order at least j+1,
then R 1 /(R 1 ∩Kα) is a simple R 1 -module. Up to isomorphism,
every C[t]-torsion-free simple R 1 -module arises in this way.
(ii) If the rational function α j has a zero at 0 of order at least
2j + 1, then R 0 /(R 0 ∩ Kα) is a simple R 0 -module. Up to
isomorphism, every C[t]-torsion-free simple R 0 -module arises
in this way.
(b) Any simple quotient of the R ˙
z -module R ˙
z /R ˙
z t is 1-dimensional.
(c) For any λ ∈ C
* , the R dotz -module R ˙
z /R ˙
z (t − λ) is simple.
(d) Let V be a simple C[t]-torsion-free R ˙
z -module. Then t acts bijec-
tively on V .
Proof. Claim (ai) is [B, Theorem 2]. Claim (aii) follows from [B, The-
orem 4.3].
To prove claim (b), note that R ˙
z t is a two-sided ideal of R ˙
z for any value
of ˙
z. The algebra R ˙
z /R ˙
z t is easily checked to be the commutative
algebra C[ts] if ˙
z = 0. Similarly, if ˙
z = 0, we have that R ˙
z /R ˙
z t ∼ =
C[t
2 s]. All simple modules over the latter commutative algebras have
dimension one.
To prove claim (c), observe that {(ts)
i |i ∈ Z + } is a basis in R ˙
z /R ˙
z (t−λ)
if ˙
z = 0. Moreover, if ˙
z = 0, then {(t
2 s)
i |i ∈ Z + } is a basis in the
quotient R ˙
z /R ˙
z (t − λ). Using this it is easy to verify that the R ˙
z -
module R ˙
z /R ˙
z (t − λ) is simple.
Claim (d) follows from the fact that tV is an R ˙
z -submodule of V and
hence is equal to V .
text.note: SIMPLE WEIGHT MODULES OVER AGEING ALGEBRA

Now we address the structure of Verma modules over age(1).
Lemma 3.
(a) Let ˙
z, ˙
h ∈ C. Then the age(1)-module M age(1) ( ˙

h) is simple if and
only if ˙

(b) Let ˙

h) = 1.
Proof. If ˙

z, ˙
h) is obviously simple al-

age(1)-module Cv with action ev = pv = qv = zv = 0 and hv = ˙
hv.
By the universal property of Verma modules, M age(1) (0, ˙
h) surjects onto
Cv and hence ¯
M age(1) (0, ˙
h) = Cv, which implies (b).
Remark 4. Lemma 3 describes all simple highest weight age(1)-mo-
dules. Let V be a simple highest weight age(1)-module. Consider the
decomposition V = ⊕ ˙

As usual, the space V

h , C) has the natural structure
of an age(1)-module defied using the canonical involution x → −x,
x ∈ age(1). The module V
⋆ is a simple lowest weight age(1)-module
text.note: SIMPLE WEIGHT MODULES OVER AGEING ALGEBRA

and the correspondence V → V

isomorphism classes of simple highest weight and simple lowest weight
modules.

The following standard result asserts that any simple weight module is
uniquely determined by any of its nonzero weight spaces.
Lemma 8. Let g be age(1) or S. Let V and W be simple weight g-
modules such that for some ˙
h ∈ wt(V ) the U(g) 0 modules V ˙
h and W ˙
h
are isomorphic. Then V ∼ = W .
text.note: SIMPLE WEIGHT MODULES OVER AGEING ALGEBRA
text.body:
Proof. Set N = V ˙
h = W ˙
h and write
U(g) =
i∈Z
U i where U i = {x ∈ U(g)|[h, y] = iy}.
Every U i is a U(g) 0 -U(g) 0 -bimodule. Consider the induced module
M := Ind

Then, by adjunction, both V and W are simple quotients of M. The

to be quotients of M/K by adjunction, we get V ∼ = W .
Now we list some properties of the age(1)-module N ˙

Lemma 9.
(a) For every i ∈ Z the U 0 -modules N ⊗ x

To prove claim (b), we observe that simplicity of N ˙

simplicity of N. Now suppose that N is a simple R ˙

Case 1. Assume ˙

Remark 10. Let N be a simple R ˙

Now we are ready to prove our main result on classification of all simple
weight age(1)-modules.
Theorem 11. Each simple weight age(1)-module is isomorphic to one
of the following simple modules:

Let V be any simple weight age(1)-module. Assume that ˙

If V has a nonzero element annihilated by q, then V is clearly a lowest
weight module. Therefore we may assume that q acts injectively on V .
Let 0 = w ∈ V ˙

The following result is a direct consequence of Theorem 11.
Corollary 12. Let V be a simple weight age(1)-module and ˙

text.body:
4. Simple weight S-modules having a simple
age(1)-submodule
In this section we classify all simple weight S-modules that have a
simple age(1)-submodule.
Let V be a simple weight age(1)-module. We have the induced weight
S-module H(V ) := Ind
S
age(1) V which can be identified with C[f ] ⊗ V as
a vector space. In this section we classify all simple quotient S-modules
of H(V ). From [DLMZ, Corollary 8] we know that the center Z(U(S))
of U(S) equals C[z, c], where

Now we can formulate the main result of this section.
Theorem 15. Let V be a simple weight age(1)-module.
(a) If V is a highest weight module over age(1), then H(V ) is a highest
weight S-module, which has a unique simple quotient.
(b) If V ∼ = ¯

(d) If V ∼ = Q

Let M be a nonzero submodule of H(V ). Then M is a weight module.

To prove claim (d), we note that V = Q

Finally, we prove claim (e). During the proof of Lemma 14 we computed
that in the module N ˙

2 (v ⊗ x

the proof.
Let age(1)
op be the parabolic subalgebra of S spanned by {f, h, p, q, z},
which is isomorphic to age(1). There are actually many simple weight
S-modules that do not contain any simple age(1)-submodule or any
simple age(1)
op -submodule. For example, if we take V to be a simple
weight sl 2 -module that is not highest or lowest weight module and
text.note:
RENCAI L ¨
U, VOLODYMYR MAZORCHUK AND KAIMING ZHAO
text.body:
˙
c = 0, then the simple S-module V
S ⊗ M H ( ˙
z)
S contains neither simple
age(1)-submodules nor simple age(1)
op -submodules.
Taking into account the results of this paper it is natural to ask whether
one can classify all simple weight S-modules or all simple age(1)-module.
text.div:
Acknowledgments. The research presented in this paper was car-
ried out during the visit of the first author to University of Waterloo
and of the second author to Wilfrid Laurier University. The first au-
thor thanks professors Wentang Kuo and Kaiming Zhao for sponsoring
his visit, and University of Waterloo for providing excellent working
conditions. The second author thanks Wilfrid Laurier University for
hospitality. We thank the referee for helpful comments and nice sug-
gestions.
R.L. is partially supported by NSF of China (Grant 11371134) and
Jiangsu Government Scholarship for Overseas Studies (JS-2013-313).
V.M. is partially supported by the Swedish Research Council.
K.Z. is partially supported by NSF of China (Grant 11271109) and
NSERC.
